questions.text: What is the normal aqueous production rate?
questions.solution:
The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2-3 μL/min. 

Formation of aqueous humor involves the following: 

  • Ultrafiltration
  • Secretion- Na/K ATPase of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process
  • Diffusion

questions.text: What is the critical angle of the air-cornea interface?
questions.solution:
The critical angle of the air–cornea interface is 46 degrees. Gonioscopy is a method of evaluating the anterior chamber (AC) angle.

Direct goniolenses include the Koeppe, Medical Workshop, Barkan, and Swan–Jacob. Indirect goniolenses include Goldmann, Zeiss, and Posner.

Structures seen on gonioscopy from anterior to posterior are: 

  • Schwalbe line: represents the posterior limit of Descemet's membrane
  • Trabecular meshwork
  • Scleral spur
  • Ciliary body and root of the iris

Shaffers grading of angle width:

Grade 4 (35–45°) is the widest angle, characteristic of myopia and pseudophakia; the ciliary body can be visualized without tilting the lens.
Grade 3 (25–35°) is an open-angle in which the scleral spur is visible.
Grade 2 (20°) is an angle in which the trabeculum but not the scleral spur can be seen.
Grade 1 (10°) is a very narrow-angle in which only the Schwalbe line, and perhaps the top of the trabeculum, can be identified.
A slit angle is one in which there is no obvious iridocorneal contact but no angle structures can be identified.
Grade 0 (0°) is closed due to iridocorneal contact.

questions.text: Which statement regarding the depth of the anterior chamber is false?

choices.text: Depth is less in women than men

questions.solution:
The depth of the anterior chamber decreases with age. 

Anterior chamber depth

  • The anterior chamber is shallow in very young and in old age.
  • At other periods of life, it is normally about 2.5 mm deep.
  • Depth is less in women than in men.
  • Depth is more in myopes.
  • Depth is less in hypermetropia and in angle-closure glaucoma

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant with large corneas, lacrimation and photophobia supported with the image is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) also known as developmental glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure(IOP) which results from the developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber.

It can be classified as:

  • True congenital or newborn glaucoma in which IOP is elevated during intrauterine life and the baby is born with ocular enlargement.
  • Infantile glaucoma: which manifests prior to age 3 years.
  • Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinical findings include:

  • Blepharospasm
  • Buphthalmos: Large eyeball due to stretching of the globe from elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Corneal enlargement:
  • Corneal haze is due to corneal edema.
  • Blue sclera - due to the shining of the underlying uveal tissue through the thinned-out sclera
  • Haab striae are healed breaks in Descemet's membrane

Treatment:

  • Goniotomy - when the angle of the anterior chamber is visible through the clear cornea.
  • Trabeculectomy when the corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle.
  • Filtration procedures such as Trabeculectomy or combined trabeculectomy with trabeculectomy if the above procedures fail.
  • Glaucoma drainage devices in unresponsive cases.

Other options:

Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood that is seen between 1-2 years.

Findings of Retinoblastoma include:

  • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex)- the most common manifestation
  • Strabismus 
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • An endophytic tumor grows into the vitreous as a white mass that may ‘seed’ into the gel. If calcification is present it gives a "cottage cheese appearance". An exophytic tumor grows outwards and causes overlying exudative retinal detachment.

The image below shows the leucocoria of the left eye.

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is an inherited corneal dystrophy that manifests since birth with endothelial degeneration. It appears as diffuse bilateral corneal edema in the absence of elevated IOP. The clinical features of the disease include corneal clouding, visual impairment, and nystagmus.

Option D: Megalocornea is a bilateral non-progressive X-linked condition that most commonly affects males. In this condition, the horizontal corneal diameter is ≥12mm(<2 years) and is ≥13 mm(>2 years). It is characterized by a clear cornea, normal corneal thickness, and no breaks in the descemet's membrane. Systemic associations of Megalocornea include Marfan's syndrome, Apert syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos, and Down syndrome.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This neonate  with complaints of photophobia and watering with large cornea and Haab's striae is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma.

Note: Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

The image given below shows Vogt's striae.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic for a change of her presbyopic glasses. This is the third time that she is coming in 2 months. What is the likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses in this patient is a symptom of open-angle glaucoma (OAG).

This is due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and nerve supply.

In intumescent cataracts, patients report difficulty with distance vision and frequent change of spectacle prescription. However, it is not associated with frequent changes of presbyopic glasses.

questions.text: Normal cup-to-disc ratio is up to_______.
questions.solution: Normal cup-to-disc ratio is up to 0.6. Although the average cup-to-disc ratio is around 0.3 to 0.4, a ratio of up to 0.6 may be found in healthy individuals. This larger ratio is frequently seen in cases of large discs, myopic discs or physiological cupping. A cup-to-disc ratio of > 0.6 is suggestive of glaucoma.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus, presents with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Examination showed a laminar dot sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with headache and eye pain along with the finding of a laminar dot sign is suggestive of glaucoma.

The laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc. This occurs because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible up to the margin of the disc.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes:

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup - 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes:

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayonetting sign - Sharp angulation of vessel at the margin of the excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: What is the last visual field to be affected in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The temporal visual field is the last field to be affected in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and finally, the nasal fibers.

Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma. 

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following is a late visual field defect in open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Bjerrum scotoma (arcuate) is a late and clinically significant visual field defect.  

Progression of visual field changes seen in glaucoma:

Early non-specific changes
  • Isopter contraction
  • Baring of a blind spot: Exclusion of blind spot from the central field
Early significant changes
  • Peripheral nasal step (may be early or late)
  • Paracentral scotoma in Bjerrum's area.
  • Siedel’s  scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot
Late significant changes
  • Arcuate or Bjerrum scotoma
  • Ring or Double arcuate scotoma: When 2 arcuate scotomas join together
  • Roenne’s central nasal step

Advanced glaucomatous field defects
  • Tubular vision
  • No light perception: Complete visual field defect.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. The pupillary reaction is sluggish and the IOP is elevated. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup and the visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the first line of treatment for this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of deterioration of vision, sluggish pupils, elevated IOP and paracentral scotoma is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Timolol is one of the first-line agents used in the treatment of primary open-angle glaucoma.

First-line agents for the treatment of glaucoma are:

  • Prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost
  • Topical beta-blockers such as timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol 
  • Selective alpha 2 adrenergic agonist brimonidine

Adjunctive therapy: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Laser trabeculoplasty: In cases where intraocular pressure (IOP) is uncontrolled despite maximal tolerated medical therapy.

Note: Since prostaglandin (PG) analogs are not included in the options, the next best option to choose is timolol.

Historically, beta-blockers were the most common first-line agents used in the medical treatment of POAG. However, with an increase in our experience with newer agents, specifically the prostaglandin analogues that facilitate outflow, they were recognized as being more efficacious in lowering IOP and systemically safer than beta-blockers. As a result, now they are the first-line agents in glaucoma treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of MI on aspirin comes with shortness of breath. She has an active history of asthma and uses inhalational bronchodilators, her last attack was 7 months ago. She was recently prescribed medications for increased intraocular pressure. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of asthma now presenting with shortness of breath after starting medications for increased intraocular pressure was most likely diagnosed with glaucoma. The drug she was likely prescribed was timolol, a non-selective beta blocker.

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals (beta-2 block on bronchi). They cause bronchospasms and are therefore contraindicated in patients with asthma (e.g. timolol, levobunolol). Ocular beta-blockers reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptors. Timolol is specifically associated with allergic blepharoconjunctivitis and punctal stenosis

Side effects: Systemic: Bronchospasm, bradycardia, decreased cardiac output, hypotension, depression, impotence, and altered lipid profile.

Contraindications: Asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, congestive heart failure, sinus bradycardia, and atrioventricular blocks

Other options:

Option A: The patient has been stable on aspirin for the past three years which is unlikely to be the cause of her current symptoms. 

Option B: Betaxolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma. 

Option C: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.

questions.text: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you have been referred a case of glaucoma. He complaints that his current medication is causing excessive drowsiness and is interfering with his work. Which of the following anti-glaucoma medications can cause drowsiness?
questions.solution:
Brimonidine is an anti-glaucoma medication that can cause drowsiness.

It is a selective alpha-2 agonist. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and, hence, causes drowsiness and CNS depression; it is contraindicated in infants and children.

A new class of glaucoma drugs, Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, promises to act specifically on the trabecular meshwork, a main outflow and blockage site in glaucoma. ROCK inhibitors are not yet approved and available for glaucoma patients. Two US companies, Aerie and Altheos, are currently in early clinical research development with topical ROCK inhibitors to lower IOP.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 55-year-old female, who is a known case of sickle cell anemia, comes to the casualty with a history of severe eye pain, redness, and diminution of vision. On examination, the visual acuity is 6/60, and there is circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, and a shallow anterior chamber. What is the drug of choice from the given options?
questions.solution:
This patient with complaints of severe headache, corneal congestion, and edema with a shallow anterior chamber most likely has acute angle closure glaucoma. Since this patient has a past history of sickle cell disease, intravenous mannitol is the drug of choice for this patient

Acetazolamide is contraindicated in cases of sickle-cell anemia since these drugs tend to increase sickling of erythrocytes.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, supported with the image of the mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow.

Angle closure can be primary, when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Classification:

Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS)
  • Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC in three or more quadrants but no peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS).
  • Intraocular pressure (IOP), optic disc, and visual field are normal.
  • No PAS are seen
  • The risk of PACG at 5 years may be around 30%.
Primary angle closure (PAC)
  • Gonioscopy shows three or more quadrants of ITC with raised IOP and/or PAS or excessive pigment smudging on the TM.
  • Normal optic disc and field.
Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
  • ITC in three or more quadrants, with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  • Optic nerve damage from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appear as typical glaucomatous cupping.

Symptoms: Pain, redness, photophobia, impaired vision, watering

Signs:

  • Corneal edema- colored halos
  • Conjunctiva- congestion, chemosis
  • IOP- elevated 40–70 mm Hg
  • AC very shallow
  • Pupil- vertically oval, mid-dilated
  • Angle- completely closed, Grade 0

Treatment:

  • Immediate- Intravenous mannitol, intravenous acetazolamide followed by oral dose, topical beta-blockers, brimonidine, latanoprost
  • Definitive- Laser peripheral iridotomy, filtration surgery

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman develops pain in the eye after dark-room/prone-provocative test. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Pain after dark-room prone-provocative test indicates occludable angles. Hence, atropine is contraindicated as it is a long-acting mydriatic and can precipitate angle closure.

Dark-room/prone-provocative test (DRPPT)- The patient sits in a dark room, face down for one hour without sleeping (sleep induces miosis). The intraocular pressure (IOP) is checked (immediately after the test, as IOP can normalize very rapidly), and an IOP rise of 8 mmHg or more is frequently considered significant.

questions.text: A young female presents with sudden onset severe pain in the left eye after watching a movie. She rushes to the hospital as there is a progressive loss of vision. She has ciliary injection and a shallow anterior chamber. The pupil is semi dilated and the cornea appears oedematous. What is the procedure of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset severe pain in the eye, progressive loss of vision, shallow anterior chamber, semi-dilated pupil, and edematous cornea is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Laser iridotomy is the procedure of choice especially in emergency situations. 

The attack may have been precipitated by pupillary dilation, which may result from activities such as going to a movie theater. Laser iridotomy re-establishes the communication between the posterior and anterior chamber, bypassing the pupillary block; hence, it immediately relieves crowding of the angle.

Various surgical and laser modalities used in glaucoma:

Angle-closure glaucoma: 

  • Laser iridotomy by Nd:Yag along with prophylactic iridotomy of the other eye → Treatment of choice.
  • Trabeculectomy → Filtration surgery

Congenital glaucoma: 

  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy

Primary open-angle glaucoma:

  • Laser trabeculoplasty: Argon or diode (if not controlled medications)
  • Trabeculectomy: Filtration surgery (if not controlled medications)

Absolute glaucoma:

  • Cyclocryotherapy
  • Nd:Yag lasercyclo destruction

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is an ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

It is a form of minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

Ex-PRESS glaucoma implant is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Complications such as hypotony are lower than with standard trabeculectomy. 

Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. While these devices were traditionally reserved for high-risk patients, or after trabeculectomy had failed, they are becoming increasingly popular. 

The commonly used devices are as follows:

1. Shunts using episcleral explants

  • Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone
  • Molteno implant - Polypropylene plate and silicone plate
  • Baerveldt implant - Silicone 

2. Mini-shunts 

  • Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel
  • iStent® - Titanium

questions.text: What is Glaukomflecken?
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken is anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity and a component of Vogt's triad seen in patients after an acute angle closure glaucoma attack. 

The Vogt's triad comprises of:

  • Glaukomflecken
  • Patches of iris atrophy
  • Slightly dilated nonreactive pupil

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless white eye with an intraocular pressure of 60 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of glaucomatocyclitic crisis.

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis/Posner–Schlossman Syndrome [PSS]) describes recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with mild anterior uveitis. The mechanism is thought to be acute trabeculitis, and there is evidence that infection, possibly cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Helicobacter pylori, may play a role. PSS typically affects young to middle-aged adults. Males are affected more frequently than females.

Signs:

  • Slit-lamp biomicroscopy typically shows a few anterior chamber cells and one to several fine white central keratic precipitates.
  • Mydriasis is common; posterior synechiae are not a feature.
  • IOP is typically raised to over 40 mmHg, out of proportion to iritis severity.
  • Gonioscopy shows an open-angle.

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids are used to control inflammation, with aqueous suppressants to lower the IOP.
  • Topical or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents may also be beneficial.

Note: In PSS, the rise in IOP is out of proportion to the pain felt. There is often a mild discomfort and pain may even be absent.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist evaluating a patient with glaucoma identifies the following finding on slit-lamp examination. What is the finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pattern of the deposition of pigments on the back of the cornea in pigmentary glaucoma. They are called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is an open-angle glaucoma having the following features:

  • Krukenberg spindles
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly, and this accumulation is called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Radial transillumination defect in the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.

Other options:

Option A: Ferry line: Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs of glaucoma surgery

Option B: Fleischer line/ring: Epithelial iron deposits at the base of the cone in keratoconus

Option C: Hudson–Stahli line: Iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between middle and lower third cornea. This finding is mainly age-related.

questions.text: Malignant glaucoma is seen in __________.
questions.solution:
Malignant glaucoma is seen after intra-ocular surgery (usually after trabeculectomy).

Ciliary block glaucoma is also called malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma. It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. 

Signs:

  • High intraocular pressure (IOP) and absent bleb.
  • Negative Seidel test.
  • Shallow anterior chamber (AC)

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is with cycloplegics (atropine 1%) to dilate the ciliary ring and push the vitreous-lens-iris posteriorly.
  • Subsequent treatment if medical therapy fails is with Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy.
  • Pars plana vitrectomy can be considered in conditions that don't respond to the above treatment modalities.

questions.text: What is iridocorneal endothelial syndrome associated with?

choices.text: Progressive atrophy of the iris stroma
Bilateral stromal edema of the iris
Deposition of glycosaminoglycans in Descemet's membrane

questions.solution:
Progressive atrophy of iris stroma is a clinical entity of iridocorneal endothelial syndrome (ICE).

ICE syndrome is a proliferative endotheliopathy, which leads to secondary angle-closure glaucoma.

It includes three clinical entities:

  1. Progressive iris atrophy
  2. Chandler’s syndrome - corneal edema
  3. Cogan–Reese syndrome - nodules and nevus on the iris; hence, it is known as iris nevus syndrome.

questions.text: What is seen in hypersecretory glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Hypersecretory glaucoma is associated with epidemic dropsy.

Epidemic dropsy occurs due to Argemone mexicana poisoning. Here, glaucoma is due to excessive production of aqueous humor.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
100-day glaucoma is a neovascular glaucoma that occurs in ischemic type of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

It is known as 100-day glaucoma because it occurs 3 months after the episode of CRVO. Although neovascular glaucoma occurs as a complication in Eale's disease (Option B) and central retinal artery occlusion (Option C) and long-term use of topical steroid therapy causes steroid-induced glaucoma (Option D) none of them are termed as 100-day glaucoma.

CRVO is further classified into two types:

  • Non-ischemic CRVO: occurs secondary to venous stasis.It is the most common type of CRVO of the two.
  • Ischemic CRVO: occurs due to acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is also termed as hemorrhagic retinopathy.

Ischemic CRVO presents with sudden loss of vision and Relative afferent pupil defect(RAPD).

Fundus examination shows massive enlargement of retinal veins and massive retinal hemorrhages giving a "splashed tomato appearance". Other findings include cotton wool spots, optic disc edema and neovascularization at the disc and in the periphery.

Pathagnomic features of ischemic CRVO that differentiates it from non-ischemic CRVO are:

  • RAPD
  • Reduced amplitude of B-wave on electroretinogram
  • Visual field defects

Complications of the disease:

  • Neovascular Glaucoma known as 100 day glaucoma
  • Neovascularisation of iris known as Rubeosis iridis
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Proliferative retinopathy

The below-given fundus image is of the "splashed tomato" appearance of CRVO. 

Option B: Eales disease is an idiopathic inflammatory disease of the peripheral retinal veins.It is considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction to the tubercular proteins and it is commonly seen in young males. It is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhage.

Complications include:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Proliferative vitreoretinopathy
  • Tractional retinal detachment,
  • Rubeosis iridis

Option C: Central retinal artery occlusion(CRAO) is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. It presents as sudden painless loss of vision and amaurosis fugax (transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia). Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot.

Neovascular glaucoma may occur as a delayed complication of CRAO but it is not termed as 100 day glaucoma.

The below image depicts the fundus image seen in CRAO with the cherry red spot.

Option D:Steroid induced glaucoma is a type of secondary open angle glaucoma that usually follows weeks-months of topical steroid therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma?

choices.text: Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the onset of POAG
Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Family history is not a risk factor for POAG development
Increased cup disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development

questions.solution:
Family history is a risk factor for the development of primary open-angle glaucoma.

Ocular hypertension (OHT) is characterized by only raised intraocular pressure (IOP). Optic disc and normal visual field are normal, with no evidence of angle closure.

Risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma include the following:

  • African American race
  • Thin cornea
  • Increasing age
  • Increased cup-disc ratio
  • Increased IOP
  • Family history of POAG

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Baerveldt implant which is a glaucoma drainage device (GDD)/seton/aqueous shunt.

It consists of a scleral plate that is sutured to the sclera and a tube connecting it into the anterior chamber. It is valveless, and hence, it carries the risk of postoperative hypotony due to excessive aqueous drainage.

Glaucoma drainage devices are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. The glaucoma valve implant is also known as a seton.

The commonly used devices are as follows:

1. Shunts using episcleral explants

  • Ahmed glaucoma valve: Silicone
  • Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
  • Baerveldt implant- Silicone 

2. Mini-shunts 

  • Ex-Press™ Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel 
  • iStent®- Titanium

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for inverse glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for inverse glaucoma is atropine.

Inverse glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by the flow of aqueous humour posteriorly to the posterior segment instead of the posterior chamber. The increased pressure in the posterior segment pushes the lens forward leading to the shallowing of the anterior chamber.

Miotics are contraindicated as they can cause the ciliary zonules to slack, the lens to move forward and further shallowing of the anterior chamber. So mydriatic and cycloplegic agents such as atropine are administered.

Inverse glaucoma is also called:

  • Malignant glaucoma
  • Ciliary block glaucoma
  • Aqueous misdirection.

Note:

Pilocarpine is the drug of choice in angle-closure glaucoma but is contraindicated in inverse glaucoma.

Whereas, atropine is the drug of choice in inverse glaucoma but is contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known case of diabetes presents with blurry vision near the center of his field of vision. He also informs that colours appear washed out or faded. His IOP was found to be elevated. Which of the following drugs should not be used to control IOP in this diabetic patient?
questions.solution:
This diabetic patient with new onset central loss of vision and reports of colors appearing faded or washed out most likely has macular edema. Prostaglandin analogs have a high propensity to cause and further exacerbate cystoid macular edema and hence are not preferred in this patient. 

Drugs associated with cystoid macular edema (CME):

  1. Prostaglandin analogues
  2. Epinephrine
  3. Dipivefrine (only the non-selective alpha agonists, in aphakic eyes)
  4. Tamoxifen
  5. Timolol
  6. Docetaxel
  7. Interferons
  8. Fingolimod
  9. Thiazolinediones
  10. Niacin (pseudo-CME)

questions.text: In a 55-year-old patient presenting with secondary open-angle glaucoma, what is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Pseudoexfoliation (PEX) syndrome is the most likely cause of secondary open-angle glaucoma.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an ocular manifestation of an age-related systemic disorder of the extracellular matrix, characterized by the production and progressive accumulation of fibrillar extracellular material in many ocular and systemic tissues. The clinical hallmark of PEX syndrome is the deposition of whitish abnormal pseudoexfoliative debris on the anterior lens capsule. 

A deposition is also noted on:

  • Zonules (causing zonulolysis and phacodonesis, lens subluxation)
  • Pupillary margin
  • Trabecular meshwork (causing the secondary open-angle glaucoma)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases the uveoscleral outflow?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. 

Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text:
True regarding POAG:

A. Abnormality of the trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy
B. Family members are likely to develop steroid responsiveness.
C. Dilatation of the pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP
D. First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG
E. Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio
questions.solution:
In primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), family members are likely to develop steroid responsiveness (statement B) and visual field defect can exist with a normal C:D ratio (statement E).

Statement A: Gonioscopy cannot visualize the specific abnormalities that occur in the trabecular meshwork in POAG. Gonioscopy diagnoses POAG because of the visibility of all the structures of the angle of the anterior chamber in contrast to the non-visibility of different structures in angle closure glaucoma.

Statement C: Primary angle-closure glaucoma is associated with exacerbation of IOP with pupillary dilatation and not POAG.

Statement D: There is a 10% increased risk of POAG in siblings and a 4% increased risk in children of patients with POAG. 

POAG also known as chronic simple glaucoma of adult-onset is characterized by the presence of any 2 of the following 3 categories of changes:

  • Increased intraocular pressure:
    • IOP >21mmHg on more than one occasion, and/or
    • Circadian variation in IOP of >8 mmHg, or
    • Asymmetry in IOP > 5 mmHg between both eyes
  • Optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage. These may include one or more of the following changes:
    • Vertically oval cup
    • Cup-disc (C:D) ratio > 0.6 (average cup: disc ratio 0.3-0.4)
    • Asymmetry in C:D ratio > 0.2 between both eyes.
    • Narrowing, notching, or pallor of the neuroretinal rim.
    • Disc haemorrhages
    • Nasal shifting of retinal vessels-Bayonetting sign
    • Lamellar dot sign
  • Visual field changes - isopter contraction, barring of blind spot, paracentral scotoma, Seidel's scotoma, Bjerrum's scotoma, double arcuate scotoma, and Roenne's central nasal step.

A patient presenting with just raised IOP and visual field defects with normal optic nerve head findings such as a normal C:D ratio can still be diagnosed as POAG (statement E).

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady was started on an ocular medication that she was instructed to take daily. She develops redness of the eye. Examination reveals a colour change of the iris and orbital fat atrophy. Which of the following medications was she likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a patient that has iris pigmentation and redness of the eye, was most likely started on latanoprost.

Drug Side Effects
Latanoprost

Allergic conjunctival hyperemia, permanent increase in iris pigmentation, orbital fat atrophy.
Timolol  Exacerbation of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence 
Scopolamine Photosensitivity, blurred vision 
Pilocarpine Corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia, decreased vision, brow ache, retinal detachment

questions.text: First drug to be given in acute angle-closure glaucoma is _________.
questions.solution:
The first drug to be given in acute angle-closure glaucoma is oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol.

Acetazolamide reduces IOP by decreasing the production of aqueous.

The definitive drug is pilocarpine as it constricts the pupil and breaks the attack.

Finally, when the corneal edema resolves, the patient has to undergo laser iridotomy to prevent such attacks in the future. So, laser iridotomy is the definitive management for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: The normal extent of the visual field superiorly is ________.
questions.solution:
The extent of visual field superiorly is 50°

Normal extent of the visual field: 

  • Temporal: 90°/100°
  • Inferiorly: 70°
  • Nasal: 60°
  • Superiorly: 50°

Note: According to Parson's 22nd Ed., Page no. 101, the visual field extends 60o superiorly. However, most journals and other standard textbooks consider the answer to be 50o. Hence, we choose 50o as the most appropriate answer.
